730757f-a.text:
Rush Construction of World's Longest Suspension Bridge. Right, construction work on one of the piers of the great Hudson River Bridge which will be opened in 1932 at a cost of about 170 million. The Bridge will connect Manhattan(lower right) between 178th Street and 179th Street and Fort Lee, New Jersey(left) where another pier is shown. The distance between the two piers, from which the Bridge will be suspended, is 3,500 feet -- over twice the length of the longest suspension bridge at present
(Camden-Philadelphia span).
n.d.  Underwood and Underwood
730757f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the world's longest suspension bridge.]

730758f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: Three views showing the construction period attendant to this public work that connects Manhattan, New York to New Jersey. The first two views are of the New York Approach, while the third is of the Jersey side.
Views: 1-2 February 1931
View : 3 August 1929
George L. Balgue
730758f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the bridge, connecting Manhattan, New York to New Jersey.]

730758f-c.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the bridge, connecting Manhattan, New York to New Jersey.]

730759f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: A northward view up the North (Hudson) River showing the cables and piers of the uncompleted structure. Manhattan is on the right and New Jersey on the left. Note the United States Navy vessels off of Riverside Drive. View No. 2 is a close up of the Manhattan base. Note here, at the left, the small lighthouse on a promontory, the historic significance of which goes back to the Revolution, as it was from here that the chains extended across the River. Apartments seen in the background form the area known as Washington Heights.
May 10, 1930
gift of W. A. Lucas
730759f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]

Four square blocks of modern apartment buildings; sacrificed to make clearance for the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge, at approximately West 181st Street, in Manhattan.
Late 1930.7
Ewing Galloway.

730767f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge, in its majestic span of the Hudson River; from West 181st Street in Manhattan, to Fort Lee in New Jersey; as see looking west to the Palisades from Manhattan. An added feature of this Bridge are the two observation platforms, atop both towers.
About 1932.
Wurts Brothers.

730768f.text:
An aerial view of George Washington Bridge, east from New Jersey,across to the Bronx. The older Washington Bridge, which spans the Harlem River,may be seen in the background, in the upper right corner.

International Photos
No Reproductions

730775f-a.text:
The George Washington Bridge, a steel structure, connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey. The view is westward from Manhattan, and just south of the Bridge. Control of this engineering masterpiece, is in the hands of the N.Y. Port Authority, who will charge a toll for crossing same. These 4 views are more or less similar, and are
all by the same photographer.
1936.
Walter L. Bogert.
730775f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey.]

730776f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: A set of 4 views of same, taken from several different angles and showing in No. 1, a view westward to the Jersey Palisades; in No. 2, a perspective northward up the River; in No. 3, a vista southward of Manhattan, and in No. 4, the structural steelwork against the Washington Heights area of upper Manhattan.
iw61

730777f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: The Manhattan support as viewed southward on the Hudson River. Note the light house at its base. This is the last of its kind left on the island of Manhattan.
July 19, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

730779f-a.text:
George Washington Bridge: A set of 2 views southwestward from Dr. Chas. V. Paterno's estate on the east bank of the North (Hudson) River, showing this span connecting Manhattan with Jersey thru a ribbon of steel. The castellated structure at the left is the home of the aforementioned individual and is at this time being razed to provide an apartment site. For views see Cabrini Blvd.
August 23, 1938.
Viewsl and 2
P. L. Sperr
730779f-a.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]

730780f.text:
The George Washington Bridge at night as photographed southwestward from Fort Tryon Park inManhattan.
1939
Alexander Alland
This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y.' by Folix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
730780f.title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [View of the bridge at night from Fort Tryon Park.]
